titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Peace and Social Justice Program (PSJ), Office Files of Mary E. McClymont
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Peace and Social Justice Program (PSJ), Office Files of Mary E. McClymont FA594

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-03-13 15:01:25 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Peace and Social Justice Program (PSJ), Office Files of Mary E. McClymont

bioghist.head: Organizational History
bioghist.p: When Susan Berresford became President of the Foundation in 1996, she established a new program structure consisting of three large thematic programs. Peace and Social Justice (PSJ) was one of these three programs. Its overall mission was to help improve government performance and accountability, foster a thriving independent civil society, and promote human rights. It was comprised of two global units: Governance and Civil Society, and Human Rights. In 2009, Peace and Social Justice became the Democracy, Rights and Justice Program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The office files of Mary E. McClymont span from 1969 to 2008, with the bulk of the records date from 1981 to 2008. The files contain extensive information about the Global Law Programs Learning Initiative (GLPLI). The Initiative studied and documented the Foundation's work in the legal field to promote legal reform, public interest law and access to justice from 1998 to 2001. According to a 1998 memorandum, the purpose of the project was to review past and current Foundation grants in order to guide future programming. The end result was the book, Many Roads to Justice. The book was translated into several languages and distributed to nonprofit organizations around the globe.

The collection contains information about the Comparative Constitutionalism Project. Developed and administered by the Governance unit of Peace and Social Justice, the project studied alternative political arrangements for promoting pluralism in diverse societies. Constitutionalism in Africa (1999-2000) was a focus, as the Foundation's goal was to encourage ethnic harmony without forcing homogenization on autonomous cultures and communities.
The collection also contains McClymont's chronological correspondence files from 1988-1990 and program officer memos from Peace and Social Justice program staff.

Other files pertain to grantees or Foundation policy. The files related to the Learning Enhancements Fund are particularly illustrative in regards to Foundation policy. They document the internal Foundation process behind how grant assessments were made, and include a practical guide for program staff files.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The original volume of 14 cubic feet accessioned by the Ford Foundation Archives in 2011 was reduced during processing to 6.3 cubic feet.
Duplicates, reference files, grant proposals, and files that addressed purely financial matters were not retained.

In 2023, in an effort to consolidate the McClymont materials, the chronological correspondence files and Haitian Task Force file that were originally part of FA674 Ford Foundation records, Peace and Social Justice Program (PSJ), Office Files of Mary E. McClymont were added to Series 3: Subject Files. The files from Accessions 2019:179 and 2020:017 were also added to Series 3: Subject Files at this time as well.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

When requesting to view audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916). Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact a RAC archivist for further instruction.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Rockefeller Archive Center received four accessions of Mary McClymont's files from the Ford Foundation between 2011 and 2020 - Accessions 2011:073, 2012:084, 2019:179, and 2020:017.

did.unittitle: Board of Trustees

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files contain dockets for meetings of the Board of Trustees. Several of the files also contain handwritten notes, memoranda or discussion papers relating to meetings of the Board or the Board's Audit and Management Committee.

Subject Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mary McClymont kept subject files on grantees and grant projects, Ford Foundation policy, and areas where Foundation policy directly impacted grant projects, such as Foundation support for affirmative action. This series also contains chronological correspondence files from 1988-1990 and program officer memos from Peace and Social Justice program staff.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The beginning of the series is arranged alphabetically. The subject files in this series received by the Rockefeller Archive Center in 2019 and 2020 were added following the alphabetical materials and is arranged as received.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains reports by consultants and Ford program staff. A number of the reports were created before Ms. McClymont joined the Foundation in 1988. Topics include legal reform and human rights work in Latin America. A few reports pertain to democratization and human rights in Chile. Other reports discuss legal reform in Vietnam, citizenship in Brazil, and university law clinics in South America. This series also holds several reports on trips to Sri Lanka, Latin America, and Russia, the Czech Republic and Poland.
